segments.text: Okay.
You were a captain in the Army Reserve up in Wisconsin then?
No, I never was a First Lieutenant in the either the Reserves or the National Guard, but think nothing of that.
standing operating procedure in both the Reserves and the National Guard.

Well in Wisconsin, first you were in Texas you were in the Army Reserve and then you switched to the National Guard in New Mexico and now when you came to Wisconsin were you in the Army Reserve or were you in the National Guard of Wisconsin?
I reverted to the Army Reserve.
Okay, so you're in the Army Reserve, okay.

and I pretty well ignored the Army Reserve, except in those days, and still I suppose, a reserve officer had to show some interest in his status as a reserve officer in order to have his commission extended
beyond five years.

Now, if he ignored the fact that he hadn't qualified himself for further extension, within the next five years he could do something that would manifest enough interest and participation to be commissioned for another five years and available for call.
Well to make a long story short, while I was at, I left New Mexico for a job in Michigan College of Mines.
Well that was a new job and I ignored the reserves for two years, the two years that I was there.
I just didn't take any correspondence courses.
I refused to go to any of their summer sessions, two weeks of summer tours.
I waived it because I had enough credits from correspondence courses to get me over the tide.
So by taking correspondence courses, I stayed in the Reserve Corps, stayed on the active duty list,
eligible for call until I got involved in the National Guard.
Now, I became acquainted with this lawyer White when I was finishing a course on a rather elementary course.
All of those courses were elementary as hell.
and in topographic reading of maps and the topographic use of maps, and they were in topographics.
So, I took a correspondence course on it, got a passing grade on everything, so I ran into the captain and I says,
I just finished the course and the correspondents said, you guys have to take it.
I'll help you out on it.
I've got there.
I've got there, done the course, got my solutions, got their solutions, Brack.
I says, if you want to use this as a training aid with your troops, why, you can have it.
Well, he says, that's fine, I didn't know who you were, you must say the lieutenant in the guard in the reserves.
I says, that's all I am and that's all I expect to be.
Because I've got, I'm working on the side projects and teaching school, doing all I can.
He says, well, he says, thanks.

So, I didn't know it at the time, but he was trying to get rid of the job of captain to give more attention to his law practice and he was really doing, setting the world on fire as a lawyer and justly so.
He was a brilliant man.
So when he went up to the Adjutant General and told him that he wanted to get rid of the job, he said, well who's your first lieutenant?
Well can he take over?
Yeah, he can take over.
So they gave the second, the first lieutenant, he was an optometrist.
in town and a darn good man and a good soldier.
He came up, took the physical examination and so forth, and he busted the physical.
Now a lot of people think that you can do, get away with anything in the Guard because they do do things when it's necessary.
that is sometimes not according to the rules.
Alright, here was a guy that had busted the examination for captain.
Well, where's the second lieutenant?
Well, it just so happened that week the second lieutenant had been arrested for bootlegging.
It was a mild operation.
I don't know why they strained at such and that as that, but they strained at it and says, no, we got to get somebody else.
So then the lawyer told him, said, well, there's one other guy in town that could take it over and make
do an even better job than I have done.
He says, bragging on me.
He says he could take it, but he says he's busy as hell.
He's working at the college and he's nursing a PhD project.
Says he'll turn it down flat.
Well he says, let me talk to him.
He says, well you come up and talk to him.
So the accident general came up and talked to me, and he was a very persuasive fella.
Are you taking at the moment?
Mm-hmm.
Would you try to talk to us?
He talked to you.
Oh, not in the heat, but I just... Yeah, he was...
I cut that air conditioning too far back in the night.
So, see...
He was a...
This accident general was...
little short of being a genius himself.
Talk about a guy that could juggle and keep several balls in the air.
He was one of them.
In fact, he's the man that invented, thought up, and helped to create the CCC.
Civilian.
Yeah, a conservation clerk.
He dreamed the whole thing up and organized it to put on in Wisconsin.
And then the then governor was the younger brother of the senator from Wisconsin.
So he showed the structure and the plan and everything to Senator La Follette.
And then they got ahold of the cabinet, and I think about three of the cabinet members modestly claimed credit for putting the whole thing, dreaming it up and putting it on the road.
Not to mention the congressmen that put up the money.
So the CCC was a product of Ralph Emmel.
I double M-E-L-L.
He was a Scandinavian son of a Scandinavian family down close to La Crosse.
And he must have convinced you then to become the captain.
Well, he himself had been promoted through the ranks.
He came back from Europe where he had been a
first lieutenant or captain in the Yankee Division.
He had gotten separated from the, well he went in there from college, Corps of Cadets at Madison and went to Officer Candidate School.
He came out of the Corps of Captains and
At a very young age he was picked for adjutant general by a very fine and sensible governor that we had back in that era.
And the job was his until he was 64 years old.
That was written into the law.
They didn't believe that every governor that came along should have a right to
name is Adjutant General.
So they just took care of it by saying this is a job that a man holds to a certain age.
That's the retiring age of the regular army at that time.
And so he inherited the job and I think he had gone through the grades rather rapidly and at that time was a Brigadier General.
and that's the general of the state.
And he was a fellow that knew how to break rules logically and successfully.
And he could do it.
So he convinced you to become the captain?
He talked me into it.
And then did you go to summer camps during the 1930s in Wisconsin?
Yeah, I went to the first summer camp
after I was captain, and White helped me pick.
White, by the way, in order to get from under the military load, White, when he vacated the job as captain, Emil talked him into accepting a staff job
as first lieutenant back in the guard.
He says, this way you won't have anything to do except be in camp.
And he says, you don't even have to take correspondence courses.
You just be in camp.
We need people like you on the list when it comes to mobilization.
quirk of fate, White became my lieutenant colonel and happily served and did a hell of a good job on mobilization.
So things, the National Guard can break regulations with the regular army any damn time they want to if they, if it's a sensible thing to do and it works out.
But if it doesn't work out, the guard will find it out before the regular army does.
And it'll be corrected.
When did you start mobilizing, in 1940?
That date, let you read there.
October 15, 1940.
That's when I started my five year leave of absence.
And all of the guards were mobilized at that time in Wisconsin or just select individuals?
No, it's not practical.
It's all the railroads, the railroads right today and the highway equipment couldn't stand the strain of mobilizing all the guard.
as of a certain week, normally in the autumn, or whenever it had to be.
But, so the War Department and the Guard and the regular Army had learned a lot in World War I.
They learned that the old square division, which in World War I had 29,000 officers and men.
Now, when we got automobiles, and the reason we got trucks to pull the cannon and trucks to carry the ammunition
and became liberated of the horses.
Now the regular army clung to the horses for at least 10 of their regiments of artillery.
As late as 1942, I think we had a few horse regiments.
Yes, the horse-drawn battalions were
in the, all in, had simmered down to one division.
That was the cavalry division that was still patrolling the border.
A company, a troop or two near Del Rio there.
Then the division headquarters in San Antonio.
And then they had, I think the end of the other end of the line, they had usually a Negro regiment down in Brownsville.
There was a cavalry out there.
Then out the other way, they went to California.
with detachments of horse cavalry here and there.
That's the time of the Columbus raid, for example.
So they couldn't take the strain.
Yeah.
And when they mobilized you and made you a colonel, what assignment did they give you?
What were you in charge of?
What was I in charge of?
Well, the batteries of the 120th Field Artillery Regiment.
were scattered in small towns.
And so, when the time came for us to be mobilized, we converged at Camp McCoy.
The way I know of that is in Wisconsin.
Yeah, well that's the traditional training ground.
It's now Fort McCoy, they call it.
That merely gives it a more euphonious permanent status, I guess.
Still the same McCoy.
And did you start training there?
No, we didn't start training there.
Each battery came down with its own motorized equipment.
Oh, I see.
Now, the Guard has been entirely motorized, except the cavalry regiments of the Guard.
And there was a cavalry division of horse cavalry.
When, at the time of the big mobilization,
But our mobilization was very simple.
It was, men were notified, we received recruits if anybody wanted to go, and we had a vacancy.
Well, that was a time where you, that was one time in recruiting where you could pick and choose.
Because the minute that the word is out,
guard in this small town was going out.
By then, a lot of the young bucks that had been too lazy to participate in the guard say, well, if they're going to do something, it'd be interesting.
Yeah, sure, I'd like to be in.
So we, each unit in each town had a waiting list.
Went off and left people that would have been listed if there had been a vacancy.
So...
We went in our own rolling equipment.
And plus, a certain number of people could go with, usually officers are well-known non-commissioned officers, known to be highly reliable.
Only those could have their own car, and their car couldn't go with the caravan.
But they had to be where the caravan was to be at the end of the day's march.
So we had individual batteries, went individually to Camp McCoy.
The 1st Battalion was with modifications here and there for geographical reasons.
The 1st Battalion moved out 24 hours ahead of the 2nd Battalion.
And where the 1st Battalion stayed their first night, and let us say
Well, let us say the Illinois National Guard Armory or Drill Grounds or something in Rockford.
Rockford is right south of Beloit.
Yes.
Rockford, Illinois.
Yeah, I think now they went as far as Rockford, Illinois.
But we stayed all night at McCoy.
The next day we lined up and drove, went as a military serial, motor serial, and it was a motor march from there to Rockford.
We moved into the facilities that they used, stoves, sleeping space in the armory, all that stuff.
We moved out of that nest
and followed the other one, I think the next nest was somewhere down around Memphis, or Cairo, Illinois, somewhere down there.
And the next one was in Vicksburg, and then from Vicksburg to the final rendezvous at supposed to be Camp Livingston.
at Louisiana, that town north of Alexandria.
They had a National Guard training field and encampment installation for the Louisiana National Guard.
We moved into the 32nd Division, moved into that place,
had to substitute until they got Camp Livingston built.
Now the artillery brigade was billeted.
The division overflowed the facilities actually at Camp Beauregard.
So the artillery brigade with the 120th part of it, a third of it,
had to go out to a kind of a hill rising from the marshes around it.
I think they called it Blueberry Hill.
And on its slopes and ridges, we went into what became known as Camp Disregard.
We were in Camp Disregard.
for four months while they were finishing Camp Livingston.

And of course when Livingston was finished, as fast as they finished it, we moved over there and finally the entire brigade of the square division and the entire square division was billeted in Camp Livingston.
and it was from Camp Livingston, that the 32nd Division was alerted for overseas movement.
And now I know that I'm going to say something that somebody's going to dispute.
But the first division to be alerted for an overseas movement
after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, when it was a known fact that we were in up to our eyes, the first division alerted to go overseas was the 32nd Division.
And the alert and the man who selected it was none other than Lieutenant General
He's a German.
As a matter of fact, his nickname in the Army was Herman the German, but he was really one of the most brilliant Army officers I've ever met.
His name will come to me in a minute.
Where was he assigned?
He was commander of the 1st Army Area.
And the 1st Army Area consisted of the consolidation of two corps areas.
The general that I'm trying to think of
is the general that MacArthur wired, demanded.
He didn't, when MacArthur dealt with the chief of staff that day, he didn't ask him to do something, he didn't tell him what to do.
He told him that he wanted the general that was out there replaced by this guy that was in the campaign of his name.
Kroger.
Yeah.
His nickname, it made him mad when he heard it.
And it's a nickname that he had that he didn't like, so I'm reluctant to write it into the record here.
But his nickname was Herman the German.
Now that had, he was, Kruger was really one of the outstanding generals of this war.
Especially out in the Pacific here.
Out in the Pacific.
And he was over age.
The chief of staffs, I have to stop and think of a lot of these old army names because they get mixed up.
The chief of staff had written in his requirements.
In fact, the chief of staff... George Marshall.
Yeah, how in the hell can you forget that name?
It's just when you want to use it.
George Marshall created an age scale and he had decided that no general officer would go overseas
in command of troops that was over 60 years of age.
Because the colonel's list was literally cluttered up with old men just waiting to become 64.
That was his logic.
So there'd be no general in command of troops
and I might go over there as an inspector or something like that.
But to exercise a command, he had to be a major general in command of a division.
He had to be at least under 61.
Now, to the best of my knowledge, Krueger
is the only man that did go overseas to a command assignment, battlefield assignments.
I think he's the only one on the list.
Now anybody can check it out if they want to by getting the officer list of that era and whatnot.
Where did Kruger send you?
Kruger didn't send me.
I was detached from the division to take an assignment in the 5th Corps as commander of another regiment.
So the fellow that transferred me out was a lieutenant general.
See their faces.
Daley.
Daley was a lieutenant general and commanding the fifth corps.
And the fifth corps at that time was a very, very big list of troops.
The word corps is a rather flexible term.
It is, consists of a corps headquarters, an artillery brigade, and two or three separate regiments, such as medical regiments and engineer regiments, and then sundry battalions,
and finally you get down to a company of military police, which is probably the smallest command in the Corps.
So, to get back to the basic question, the 32nd Division, the day after Pearl Harbor,
Well, I think during the bombardment of Pearl Harbor, the San Antonio man, Herman the German, called Major General commanding the 32nd Division and the two brigadiers
and also the similar ranks of the 37th Division.
Now it was a square division like we were, but it was over in Alabama at Camp Shelby, and Shelby was in his Army area, so he had
Those two, those six officers and I don't know from how many other divisions, if any, he may have called.
But the Brigadier General of Infantry that was included in the call from the 32nd and our Major General
that was in the same call, their stories jived as to what happened.
They went down there and Krueger said, well gentlemen, now there were some other officers there, but they could have been staff officers.
He had quite a little huddle.

but I know those two divisions were there represented because I knew all six of them personally because later on I was right next door to this 37th division while I was over there as a regimental commander because I got one of the regiments that was in the field artillery brigade

Now they came back and old Herman the German or Kruger says to them, I'm sorry to tell you gentlemen, but you and you and you and you and everybody except the major general commanding the 37th division who was a young state engineer of Ohio, he says,
you fellows are out of age for overseas duty.
And he says you will be retained in the service, you will be given assignments in the troop training program that is now looming ahead of us as something phenomenal.
Says instead of two million men overseas,
that we did in World War I, we've got to think in terms of millions on two fronts.
For the first time in history, we're on the two front war.
And he says, we'll need all of you.
But for field service, he has this wage scale, this age scale.
And we've been enforcing it, published it, and enforcing it on colonels, lieutenant colonels, majors, and captains.
And he says, the chief of staff and their studies have set up this age scale, and you've been weeding out your overage captains, you've been weeding out your overage
age majors and all of you have at least one or two colonels that are over 60.
It says as a matter of fact the top age for a colonel is 58 and as you know the top age for a lieutenant colonel is I think it's 52 yeah and the over age limit for a major
is 48, and says now that age list in some of your divisions and regiments has not been clearly, uh, shaken out.
Says these people are over age, are to be retained here as trainers.
But says these, the bunch that are going out now,
the first echelons overseas.
This is the age scale.
Well, you were well within that age for a colonel.
So, that meant to you that you were going overseas.
Sure.
Incidentally, all the colonels of artillery went overseas in grade, in the 32nd Division, because we had already zealously, I had

The age and grade problem had already been solved in the 120th Field Artillery when the bombardment came and the Soho crowd had been equally zealous in getting down to the nitty-gritty and complying with it.
Now you say, well who made up that?
Who says that
a guy that's 42 and just mediocre should be retained and a guy that's 47 that's twice as healthy and well and happy and a better field officer.
Why should he be, well maybe he shouldn't go to be a good trainer, but why should he be
Why should this more or less weak sister here be retained because he's 42 and got a chronic something wrong with him that impairs his efficiency?
You have to keep this guy, but you have to lose that guy.
I've never solved that and I don't believe it was soundly executed, but
Did you go into the first campaign, into our North African campaign?
You were in the European Theater.
We were in the European Theater when the people that went out on this first pickup to get back to the meeting down there, he said that he was, they were sending over
heavily reinforced corps, he told his generals, after he broke the news to it, who among them was going to stay in his assignment and who wasn't.
He says the, you will go back to your units and triangularize them.
Well, that's no big job.
The entire triangular division comes out of one square division.
In other words, you slough off, you're sloughing off units instead of men.
So, he says you're to go back and triangularize yourself from a square division of about 23,000 men

down to a triangular rise division of about 1,500 men, 15,000 men, officers and men, and says having done that, and of course you'll picture a vest and keep all you can that you think ought to be going out in this advanced corps, this reinforced corps will

move without delay, that's to mean as far as you can, as soon as you can get the stuff on the railroad, as soon as the railroads can haul you and all that, but you will proceed without delay to ports of embarkation in the area of Boston, and after you've slept off these surplus units,
picked out the best you've got left over out of the part of that.
And it'll also consist of at least four divisions.
It'll be, its code name will be Force Magnet.
So you can just forget the core name.
It'll be Force Magnet.
And Magnet will have in it

at least three or four or maybe five divisions with appropriate number of non-divisional troops to make up a big corps or maybe two corps and the two corps would be you see an army is two or more corps
So you debarked, or you left then for Boston?
No, you don't, as he says, you don't move this all at once.
First, you got to stuff off these other, the surplus regiments and battalions and companies, and you set them over here in one part of the reservation, and get this other
new division, triangularized division.
It takes 24 hours of staff discussion and whatnot to get the list.
Then shifting them around on the camp area so that they'll begin working as a unit in their training and whatnot while they're getting, we knew it was Christmas time at the end
So, this is Christmas 42?
You can't get in a railroad haulage at that time.
It's all tied up with commerce and passenger traffic.
Well, when did you leave for Europe now?
I didn't get out.
This core artillery brigade was toward the bottom of the list.
It was right after the last full division.
So,
and my regiment within that artillery brigade had an especially high priority rate so that it would be the first regiment to go out of the brigade.
So I didn't, with all the...
